page.title: 20 SIR ROBERT PEEL
page.content: Robert Peel was born at Chamber Hall, Bury the son of a cotton magnate. At 21 he became Member of Parliament for Tamworth. During his political career he formed the Metropolitan Police in 1829. These men became known as "Bobbies" or "Peelers" after his name. He became Prime Minister in 1834 and 1841 at the head of a Conservative government. He built up the party into a major political force. His greatest achievement as far as the public was concerned was the abolition of the Corn Laws in 1846 which helped Britain on the road to Free Trade.He died in 1850 following a riding accident. In his honour a tower was erected after public subscription on Holcombe Hill which overlooks the entire Metropolitan Borough. Also a statue stands in Market Place opposite the Parish Church where he was baptised.
